The part that got me the most was the throwback to language formats - JSON, XML, etc. The whole idea of prompt engineering was to be able to ask the LLM questions in plain English. If we go back to formats, however intuitive they might be (by the way "intuitive" is highly subjective), fewer people would be able to prompt because of the learning curve. Of course, not all people are trying to create agents. It looks like context engineering is for the time being geared towards agentic programming.

Context Engineering is used when building AI agents to provide possible scenarios for the actions to take when a user makes a prompt. Context engineering is an evolution from Prompt engineering that encompasses a series of scenarios to an AI agent

Context engineering: It is about designing and building a dynamic system to an LLM with the right info at the right time to complete a task Context engineering is the practice of prompting a Large Language Model (LLM) to analyze the different scenarios of a particular problem. For example, if you were building a product, you might ask the LLM to think through its product-market fit, identify target customers, and so on.

A prompt used in a chatbot typically involves simpler, interactive back-and-forth conversation prompts. This is often what is called "prompt engineering," where you craft questions or instructions to engage the language model in dialogue or to get specific responses in a conversational manner. These prompts are generally shorter, focused on immediate interaction, and iteratively refined during the conversation. A context prompt used in an AI agent is more complex and structured. This is part of "context engineering," where you create a detailed, comprehensive prompt that acts like an instruction manual for the agent. It includes multiple components such as task instructions, tools usage, memory access, guardrails, and orchestration. This prompt often involves structured data formats (e.g., XML, JSON) and covers all possible scenarios and actions upfront because the agent operates autonomously to accomplish tasks without iterative back-and-forth interaction.

1. In simple words, context engineering is just designing right notes/infos, in right structure to LLM on which LLM performs tasks. 2. Context Engineering evolved from prompt engineering as prompt engineering is relvant from small systems like chatbot where constant human interactions are needed and when it comes to AI agents it evolves to context engineering as while building we are not going to talk it continously we need to give it prior knowledge that have all the info what it need to do for it to work end to end 3. Models, Tools, Knowledge & memory, audio & speech, GuardRails, Orchestration 4. Context Engineering relates to this 6 components by making sure how these all working together in systematic and right time 5. 6 parts are: 1. Role 2. Task 3. Input 4. Output 5. Contraints 6. Capabilities & Reminders

I call it feature engineering for agents (arxiv), similar to what people used to do in classical ML to improve the input representation. Once you have a good representation of your data (by selecting, merging, mapping, etc.), even a light model can surpass a complex models (e.g, Logistic->xgboost). For agents, these features are the context. So, it is not only the goal (pilot using big LLM), it is the system (components besides the LLM). The idea is to develop an agent/workflow/app with the smallest feasible LLM so that you are forced to improve the system (cognitive architecture) first. Of course, LM can be replaced by any other engine.
This is such an amazing resource!! I appreciate you compiling so many great supplementary content

this is super interesting. the concept of trying to achieve a procedure with as small of an LLM as feasible by optimizing context window is certainly a very useful one. just yesterday an open source opanAI llm model came out that works locally on my 9070xt and i've been copying and pasting small contexts (it can only hold a very small context window before being overly saturated) and then iterating to try to identify how (at least one small) model interprets context. i think having this stuff available on youtube is huge because we need to be transparent about work and development in this cutting edge stuff to optimize use. one thing i've realized from my limited experience is that a hallucination of an llm can be leveraged using recursion to enhance a model's performance. I'm still in my infancy of my development and learning python before i get into more advanced things like RAG and proper context (prompt) engineering (on coursera) but this was a beautiful glimpse!

Prompt Engineering = Writing text msg to LLM. Include info on role, examples, constraints to get better results. Prompt: "Find the best restaurant in India" can give results that are not very helpful to you. Refined: "You are a travel expert[Role]. Find restaurants similar to Namaste[Example]. Price per dish less than 500 INR[Constraint]" Context Engineering = PE(LLM) + Memory(preferences) + RAG(relevance) + StateManagement(step by step guidance). It enriches the input prompt making the results more personalised. Thank you for the easy explanation.

Key Points from "Advanced Context Engineering for Agents": 1. Context engineering optimizes AI coding agents for complex codebases (00:02:46) 2. Spec-first development enables managing large AI-generated code (00:03:33) 3. Goals: handle complexity, no slop, production code, shared understanding (00:03:58) 4. Naive coding agents fail by endless back-and-forth prompting (00:04:06) 5. Intentional compaction improves context usage and agent memory management (00:04:39) 6. Context window content must be carefully curated for quality (00:05:15) 7. Context engineering is key to agent effectiveness and output quality (00:05:49) 8. Minimizing token use while maximizing useful context improves results (00:06:20) 9. Sub-agents enable context control by delegating targeted codebase queries (00:06:59) 10. Frequent intentional compaction maintains context window under 40% usage (00:08:20) 11. Three-phase workflow: research, plan, implement for effective context management (00:09:00) 12. Mental alignment via code review focuses on shared understanding, not lines (00:10:00) 13. Case study: successful one-shot fix on 300k line Rust codebase (00:10:58) 14. Complex problem solved with 35k lines shipped in 7 hours (00:11:34) 15. Hierarchy of errors: bad research causes more issues than bad code (00:11:57) 16. Reviewing specs over code improves efficiency and correctness (00:12:40) 17. Future challenge: team workflow transformation harder than coding agents (00:13:10) --- Powered by VidSift Video Knowledge Engine Find us: VidSift dot me

the best compact is what i call the “tour guide”, ill post it later but generally, we track a few things in chronological order - decisions - gotchas - relevant files read, line numbers for each category of context i ask to to describe its understanding before it had the thing, and after, and why its important this has been the single greatest prompt, when u reload/clear, load that file and then say show me your understanding this realignment after a continuation is also very important i also make the handoff prompt end with next steps for the agent, so u get a copy paste block that forces the continuation research/context priming, and validation/alignment before continuing

The idea is :- It's in a multi agent setup. It has a main brain. Then the main brain has connected to more than one parent agent. Where every parent agent has access of more than one worker/child tools. The fact is that any parent agent can wrap a child or worker tool if it's needed but the child cannot wrap as a parent. When the parent gets initiated, it works like a private network which doesn't have access to the main agent memory where it has its separate dedicated memory. Also it can call any other parent agent a tool in the flow of execution. It means the current flow gets held until another called parent tool final output gets received. Another interesting thing is that the called another parent as tool can also create another private network which is fresh and does have access to the running current parent private memory. You can call this setup as multi agents I guess (but not worked in parallel)

I am highly skeptical about this. While I agree that LLM's are getting better at coding and better input yields better result, there are still areas where they lack. From my own experience, I have seen these LLMs generate an absolute garbage code that WORKS but where it is going to be interesting is if you run into an issue that LLM can't solve. Now your entire team of developers that shipped million line of code in couple months need to find out where exactly the error occurred. Being disconnected from the codebase will comeback and bite you in your ass. Been there and experienced it.

It would be better to show more results. It’s like the home woodworking channels that show fancy tools but little results. We all know what Claude Code can do and at first it’s impressive. But as it get‘s more complex and in the area where customers are willing to pay money it get‘s less and less usable. So I split between AI sessions to get some project documents and maybe an example implementation and then do the work the old way.

This will never work because production code is too fragile. You can't regenerate an entire repo. There are too many moving pieces - you'd be re-introducing thousands silent bugs and edge cases that are normally slowly ironed out. Having natural language try to be the spec is ridiculous. The scope of interpretation from natural language to code is simply.... astronomical. And if i were somehow wrong, and you could regenerate 100k+ lines based on a spec and it all works perfectly.... what makes you think the AI can't come up with the 500 line plan at that point? Humanity would be beyond cooked.

This analysis says companies are using "AI" as an excuse for layoffs. The video argues that businesses are really just "hurting" or "bloated", and they only say "AI" to make their stock price go up. This misses the main point. The business isn't "hurting" by accident. It is "hurting" because it is spending billions of dollars to buy the new AI systems. The layoffs are not an excuse; they are how they pay for the AI. This is the definition of Wage Compression. Companies are trading the high cost of human workers for the high cost of new machines. The goal is to replace the human worker permanently - or at least the vast majority of human workers.
There's a reason why Japanese companies survive so long. They don't do layoffs as much as Western companies. The employees feel safe and some even work in the same company their entire lives.

I use AI every day, it’s a glorified search engine. Not anywhere near what they are advertising. I spend more time trying to get it do what I need than it would take me to do it myself, and you spend your whole life cutting out fluff and fill words to be direct and precise and it fills the page with crap to try and sound smart.
TLDR : AI has been massively over-hyped and bosses are simply using it as an excuse to sack people they would've anyway.

AI is the new “return to office” excuse a cover-up for leadership failures behind layoffs and an attempt to make employees quit. It still struggles with basic math, yet we’re told it will transform company profits. Maybe AI will be truly effective one day, but that day isn’t coming anytime soon.

Hi Kadz. Thank you for the video. Is it common practice in this sector to have bonuses starting from a certain threshold like making 50-60k pounds in one quarter? I'm a young recruiter who started in a specialized recruitment firm less than a year ago and I've been doing fairly well, moving from a recruiter position to a recruitment consultant position after 6 months. I like the job and it has helped me push my limits further even though I am unhappy about two things mainly: 1) the lack of transparency on the P&L of my team (to better understand what I cost and what I bring) 2) the high results needed to have a bonus (earnings starting from 60k every 3 months). Also the bonuses aren't clearly written down in my contract. I don't want to be the gullible guy who generates a lot of profit for the business but only gets 5% of that. Key Takeaways for quick navigation: 00:00 Introduction Speaker introduces giving up running and the importance of personal identities. 01:01 Personal Identities' Impact Personal identities affect professional identities. Challenges for business students. 05:47 Design Thinking for Careers Using Design Thinking in career decisions. Need to explore multiple paths. Self-awareness is crucial. 07:26 Unconscious Biases Role of unconscious biases in career choices. Influence of family, peers, culture. Impact of personal identities. 10:16 Career Identity Narrative Career identity as a complex personal narrative. Encouraging self-understanding and questioning career scripts. As a recruiter myself, I focus more on job seekers personality and attitude than just skills. Giving everyone a chance is important. I tend to learn a lot from them during my interaction and it helps a lot.

This was so GOOD! As an HR professional of 15+ years, I do not look for candidates to come in and give me perfect answers to questions that they have googled based on methods such as STAR. I am also NOT a fan of keywords, or the lack there of, cancelling out resumes. I resonate with the speaker saying that they strive to give everyone a fair chance at a job...and also not wanting to miss out on a candidates because the piece of paper doesn't convey them fully. People are HUMAN - we are not automated, systematic robots. and no matter how well one incorporates the STAR method, it may get them in the door, but i guarantee it will have them on their way right back out once they start to work and their true character and personality start to come out.

You nailed it on the culture piece! So many companies write generic job descriptions that sound exactly like their competitors, then wonder why they attract the wrong people. I've been working with companies on this exact problem, and here's what I've noticed: when you SHOW your culture instead of just describing it, everything changes. A 2-minute video of your actual team interacting, your real workspace, how decisions get made - that tells candidates more than any "we're like a family" job posting ever could. The best part? People who don't fit your culture will self-select out before applying. You get fewer applications, but they're from people who actually WANT to work in your environment. It's like dating - you want someone who's excited about the real you, not some generic version you think they want to see. Have you experimented with video content to showcase culture authentically? The difference in candidate quality is pretty remarkable!

Loved this talk. A company that has talent acquisition personnel who doesn't necessarily interact with the employee once they get hired, the feedback is a lot harder to get. I agree that getting that feedback is crucial to improve your recruiting process. Thank you for the insight!
Recruiting the right people is often underestimated but truly makes or breaks a leader’s success.

The greatest challenge that I see around recruiting is the recruitment process having no bearing on the role. And, being over complicated to try and "assess" suitable and interest. Moreover, most interview processes assume the output ahead of any input e.g. a Job Description made for someone who is currently unknown
This is great, these observations are good starting points for the HR department.
People lie so much on their resume, and perform amazingly at interviews. Thank you for this TedTalk.

Wow, this talk was super insightful! We’ve been trying to up our recruiting game, and I can totally relate to what Mads is saying. We actually brought in Bolster Group to help with our process, and it was a total game changer. They really helped us figure out how to attract and keep the right people.I thought I’d share in case anyone else is struggling with this too! great talk mads

It's relatable, esp. on "leaders spend 10% of their time recruiting and 90% of their time making up for recruiting mistakes". Let me know once you already built the algorithm :) would love to try out!
I agree with this 100%. Having the right team behind you is necessary for success.

Know what skills it takes to be a good cook? The ability to follow a recipe. What skills does it take to follow a recipe? First, one needs to read the entire recipe. Then you have to look over the ingredients, make sure you have them on hand and in the qty needed, make a list of what you don't have or need and go to the store and get it. You also have to make sure you have the equipment. Don't have a grater? A juicer? A masher? Go get one or figure out a way using what you do have. Then you need to organize everything. Wet ingredients, dry ingredients what bowl sizes to hold what until you're ready to combine get the pots or cooker out. Then you need to be able to measure. Then you need to follow instructions. There may be some element of timing involved. Marinate for a 8 hours or let soak for one hour, pre-heat the oven 15 minutes before placing roast to cook for one hour per lb. So to be a GOOD cook, it requires certain skills. Time management, organization, ability to follow an instructions. So asking someone if they're a good cook or do they have a favorite recipe book or box of recipes, their answer can tell you a lot .
I agree with so much of what you are saying. However, I am on the fence about applicants “have to fit into the culture”. Some of theses leading organizations need to change their culture.

I'm halfway through this and I can't speak for others but I can speak for myself. No I don't want to hire myself and yes I want someone who specializes in specifics. I'm baffled that anyone would think this way.
This was really good and yet so hard to find ! Ray alio also has amazing stuff on hiring the best possible team.
Love it!! Game changer and confirmation that I am on the right path with my graduate school studies and plan.

While, Mads Faurholt-Jorgensen ill agree with all your points especially the fact that we all make mistakes and should learn from them (as no one is perfect including C-level execs.) by reverting back in time (through our notes) to analyse, interpret and overcome such repetitions/obstacles in the future. However id like to hear your opinion on how leaders manage to sustain their people for an elongated period under the same umbrella to overachieve and succeed.....

Recruitment, to me, it is the best area in the HR field. So inspiring words and a great thoughts about how does it work. Not every manager knows that we took all these into consideration. I almost made 3500 interviews, some of them for real jobs and some for me to train but i ended up telling candidate what are thier issues and i have noticed. Thanks

key_facts_from_comments: Context engineering involves designing dynamic systems with right information at the right time for LLMs to complete tasks.
AI agents require structured prompts that include task instructions, tools usage, memory access, and guardrails.
Prompt engineering focuses on conversational back-and-forth interactions, while context engineering supports autonomous agent operation.
Context engineering evolved from prompt engineering to address complex, non-interactive AI agent workflows.
Models, tools, knowledge, memory, audio/speech, and orchestration are core components of AI agent systems.
The video explains how context engineering enables end-to-end task execution without iterative human interaction.
Sub-agents can delegate targeted queries to manage context window size and improve efficiency.
Intentional compaction helps maintain context window usage under 40% for optimal performance.
A case study showed a 35k-line Rust codebase fixed in 7 hours using context-engineered agents.
Spec-first development improves management of large AI-generated codebases.
Memory and state management allow agents to track conversation history and user preferences without full history in each request.
RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) is a key example of context engineering in action.
Context engineering includes role definition, task specification, input/output design, constraints, and capabilities.
Agents can be designed with private networks and dedicated memory separate from main agent memory.
Multi-agent systems allow parent agents to call other parent agents as tools within execution flows.
key_opinions_from_comments: This explanation is clearer than any other I've seen on AI agents.
The video makes complex topics accessible without fluff or unnecessary distractions.
Tina’s teaching style is exceptional—clear, engaging, and respectful of the audience’s time.
AI agents should be used as assistants, not to replace entire jobs entirely.
Companies are using 'AI' as an excuse for layoffs driven by economic and structural factors.
The hype around AI replacing jobs is overblown; real issues stem from economic downturns and corporate mismanagement.
AI is more like a glorified search engine than a revolutionary replacement for human work.
The term 'context engineering' feels like rebranding rather than a new concept.
Some believe this approach will never work due to production code fragility and hidden bugs.
Real-world metrics and before/after results would strengthen the argument.
More hands-on exercises and practical examples are needed for deeper understanding.
The video's clarity is rare on YouTube—most content is bloated with filler.
AI agents are not ready to handle complex, high-stakes tasks without human oversight.
The idea of AI agents setting their own goals raises serious ethical concerns.
This content deserves more recognition—it’s a masterclass in concise technical education.
